meanings.def: the world; the planet that we live on
examples: the planet Earth
The earth revolves around the sun.
a satellite orbiting the earth
the earth's surface/crust
on earth the history of life on earth
I must be the happiest person on earth!
No one knows what happens to us after we leave this earth.
The Bible says the meek will inherit the earth.
The earth revolves on its axis.
a lost spirit, wandering the earth
humans and other species that inhabit the earth
the last asteroid that hit the earth
the moon's orbit around the earth
She believed that demons walked the earth.
when dinosaurs roamed the earth
The astronauts were able to send the information back to earth.

meanings.def: land; the hard surface of the world that is not the sea or the sky; the ground
examples: After a week at sea, it was good to feel the earth beneath our feet again.
above the earth fifty feet above the earth
under/below/beneath the earth in mines deep under the earth
You could feel the earth shake as the truck came closer.
She was sitting on the floor watching TV.
I found her lying on the ground.
The rocket crashed a few seconds after it left the ground.
It was good to be back on dry land again.
They fought both at sea and on land.
You could feel the earth shake as the truck came closer.
Furniture fell over as the room was shaken by an earth tremor.
The wreckage of the plane was scattered across the parched earth.
The bunker is located deep below the earth.

meanings.def: the substance that plants grow in
examples: a clod/mound of earth
I cleaned off the earth clinging to my boots.
Plant the seedlings in damp soil.
The car wheels got stuck in the mud.
A cloud of dust rose as the truck set off.
The tiles are made of clay.
an area of rich, fertile land
Pack the dirt firmly around the plants.
The car got stuck in the muddy ground.
They drove across miles of rough, stony ground.
I filled the pot with a handful of loose earth.
I scrambled to the top of the steep earth bank.
My boots were caked in big clods of wet earth.
The fields had been ploughed, and there was nothing but bare earth to be seen.
The plants must have their roots in the earth.
The sun beat down on the baked earth.
Dig the earth to a depth of two spade lengths.
His boots sank into the soft earth.
In the air was the smell of freshly dug earth.

meanings.def: the hole under the ground where an animal, especially a fox, lives
a wire that connects an electric circuit with the ground and makes it safe
to be, feel, look, taste, etc. very bad
to charge, etc. a lot of money
examples: I'd love that dress, but it costs the earth.
If you want a house in London, you’ll have to pay the earth for it.

meanings.def: to return, or to make somebody return, to a normal way of thinking or behaving after a time when you/they have been very excited, not very practical, etc.

examples: Keep looking—they can't just have vanished off the face of the earth.

meanings.def: to hide, especially to escape from somebody
to do everything possible, even if it is difficult, in order to get or achieve something
examples: I'd go to the ends of the earth to see her again.

meanings.def: used to emphasize the question you are asking when you are surprised or angry or cannot think of an obvious answer
examples: What on earth are you doing?
How on earth can she afford that?

meanings.def: to do everything you possibly can in order to achieve something
used after negative nouns or pronouns to emphasize what you are saying
examples: Nothing on earth would persuade me to go with him.

meanings.def: to make promises that will be impossible to keep
examples: Politicians promise the earth before an election, but things are different afterwards.

meanings.def: to find somebody/something after looking hard for a long time
a very good and honest person that you can always depend on
to destroy or remove somebody/something completely

idioms.idiom: be, feel, look, taste, etc. like nothing on earth
idioms.def: to be, feel, look, taste, etc. very bad

idioms.idiom: charge, cost, pay, etc. the earth
idioms.def: to charge, etc. a lot of money
examples: I'd love that dress, but it costs the earth.
If you want a house in London, you’ll have to pay the earth for it.

idioms.idiom: come back/down to earth (with a bang/bump) | bring somebody (back) down to earth (with a bang/bump)
idioms.def: to return, or to make somebody return, to a normal way of thinking or behaving after a time when you/they have been very excited, not very practical, etc.

idioms.idiom: disappear/vanish off the face of the earth
examples: Keep looking—they can't just have vanished off the face of the earth.

idioms.def: to hide, especially to escape from somebody

idioms.idiom: go to the ends of the earth
idioms.def: to do everything possible, even if it is difficult, in order to get or achieve something
examples: I'd go to the ends of the earth to see her again.

idioms.idiom: how, why, where, who, etc. on earth
idioms.def: used to emphasize the question you are asking when you are surprised or angry or cannot think of an obvious answer
examples: What on earth are you doing?
How on earth can she afford that?

idioms.def: to do everything you possibly can in order to achieve something
used after negative nouns or pronouns to emphasize what you are saying
examples: Nothing on earth would persuade me to go with him.

idioms.def: to make promises that will be impossible to keep
examples: Politicians promise the earth before an election, but things are different afterwards.

idioms.def: to find somebody/something after looking hard for a long time
a very good and honest person that you can always depend on

idioms.idiom: wipe somebody/something off the face of the earth | wipe something off the map
idioms.def: to destroy or remove somebody/something completely

meanings.def: to make electrical equipment safe by connecting it to the ground with a wire
